def: bounded above, upper bound, bounded below, lower bound, bounded, supremum, least upper bound, infimum, greatest lower bound, maximum, minimum.
least upper bound principle: every nonempty subset bounded above/below has a sup/inf.
section 2.3 the least upper bound principle
def: limit of a sequence, converge
the squeeze theorem: “numbers squeeze, their limits squeeze”
section 2.4 limits
proposition: if (a_n) is a convergent seq, then the set {a_n} is bounded.
thm: lim of sum, scalar product, product, quotient.
section 2.5 basic properties of limits
def: (strictly) monotone increasing
monotone convergence thm: monotone increasing bounded above converge, monotone decreasing bounded below converge.
thm: suppose lim(x_n)=L, if x_a >= a, for all n >= N, then L >= a; if x_n <= b, for all n >= N, then L <= b. (not on book)
nested interval lemma: sps nonempty interval closed each interval inside the previous interval, then the interval is nonempty.
section 2.6 monotone sequences
def: subsequence
Bolzano-Weierstrass Theorem: every bounded sequence of real numbers has a convergent subsequence.
thm: every sequence has a monotone subsequence. (not on book)
section 2.7 subsequences
proposition: (a_n) converging to L, for every epsilon > 0, there is an integer N s.t. abs(a_n - a_m) < epsilon for all m, n >= N.
def: Cauchy
proposition: every Cauchy seq is bdd.
def: complete(if every Cauchy in the set converges to a pt in set)
completeness theorem: every Cauchy sequence of R converges
section 2.8 Cauchy sequences
CHAPTER 2 The Real Numbers
D30CCB17-B8F4-4AA5-AD65-BA30811EE1AE
def: series converges, summable, infinite series, diverge.
D519E3C5-784D-421E-AA4C-F16F4DBCEB75
def: harmonic series. 1/n
[nth term condition] thm: if series converge, lim(a_n) = 0 (page 37)
1. the series converges
2. for each epsilon > 0, there is int N s.t. for all n >= N, abs(series a_k from k = n+1 till infinity) < epsilon
3. for each epsilon > 0, there is int N s.t. for all m, n >= N, abs(series a_k from k = n+1 till m) < epsilon
Cauchy criterion for series: TFAE for series:
section 3.1 convergent series
1. sequence (s_n) is bounded above, in which case, series a_n converges.
2. sequence (s_n) is unbounded implying series a_n diverges.
proposition: if a_k nonnegative, for k greater or equal to 1, s_n is the series, either

comparison test: consider 2 seq, with abs(a_n) < b_n, for all n no less than 1, if (b_n) is summable, then (a_n) is summable and abs(Series_a) <= abs(series_b). if (a_n) is not summable, then (b_n) is not summable.
if l = 1, may or may not converge
root test(aka the n-th root test): a_n nonnegative for all n, l = limsup(a_n)^(1/n). if l < 1, then series converges, if l > 1, series diverges.
proposition: (x_n) a bdd seq, L be the set of all real #s which are the limit of some subsequences of (x_n), then L has maximum and minimum. (not on book)
def: alternating sequence
Leibniz Alternating Series Test: (a_n) monotone decreasing seq, and lim(a_n) = 0, then the alternating series of it converges.
section 3.2 convergence tests for series
def: absolutely convergent (series), conditionally convergent (series)
proposition: an absolutely convergent series is convergent
def: rearrangement (a series with the same terms in a different order)
thm: every rearrangement of an absolutely convergent converges to the same limit.
rearrangement theorem: if a series is conditionally convergent, then for every real number L, there is a rearrangement that converges to L.
section 3.3 absolute and conditional convergence
CHAPTER 3 Series
A35415C2-AF6A-4EDB-BEBF-5E2FA4FC1BAC
def: points, zero vector, Euclidean norm, dot product/inner product
Schwarz inequality (equality holds when x and y are collinear)
triangle inequality (equality holds when x = 0 or y = cx.

def: orthonormal basis
A06B5EA7-ED38-43D4-9F0D-A9EF8E03B8AE
an orthonormal set in R^n is linearly independent. so an orthonormal basis for R^n is a basis and has exactly n elements.
lemma: {v_1, …, v_m} be an orthonormal set in R^n, then ||sigma(a_i)v_i (i from 1 to m)|| = square root of the sum of a_i’s square.
section 4.1 n-dimensional space
def: sequential convergence
lemma: (x_k) sequence in R^n, then limx_k = a iff lim||x_k - a|| = 0
lemma: a sequence x_k =(x_k,1,…,x_k,n) in R^n converges to a point a = (a_1,…,a_n) iff each coefficient converges: ie limx_k = a iff limx_k,i = a_i

def: Cauchy, complete (set is complete if every Cauchy seq of points in S converges to a pt in S)
completeness theorem for R^n: every Cauchy sequence in R^n converges. thus R^n is complete.
sections 4.2 convergence and completeness in R^n
def: limit point, closed
proposition: union of two closed subsets is closed. the intersection of a family of closed subsets is closed.
def: closure (smallest set containing all limits)
proposition: closure of closure is itself.
def: ball, open
5F34C6CF-FC30-4A6E-A6CE-AC3743CCC857
thm: a set is open iff its compliment is closed.
proposition: intersection of 2 open subsets is open, and the union of a family of open subsets is open.
section 4.3 closed and open subsets of R^n
def: compact (if every sequence of pts in the set has a convergent subsequence with lima = lima_k,i)
lemma: a compact subset is closed and bounded.
lemma: C is closed subset of a compact subset of R^n, then C is compact.
B2AB326B-DB11-4BFC-BB40-59FD3F4E87D7
The Heine-Borel Theorem: a subset of R^n is compact iff it is closed and bdd.
Cantor’s intersection theorem: a decreasing sequence of nonempty compact subsets of R^n, then the intersection is not empty.

def: Cantor set, nowhere dense (a set whose closure has no interior is nowhere dense), isolated (if the intersection of a ball centred in the set with any radius, is nothing but the centre, then the set is isolated)
the Cantor-Berstein-Schroeder Theorem: if there exist injective functions: f: from A to B, g: from B to A, then the cardinality of A and B are equal
section 4.4 compact sets and the Heine-Borel Theorem
CHAPTER 4 Topology of R^n

def: limit, continuous, discontinuous
def: Lipschitz function, Lipschitz constant
proposition: every Lipschitz function is continuous
corollary: every linear map A from R^n to R^m is Lipschitz, and therefore is continuous
section 5.1 limit and continuity of functions

def: removable singularity, heaviside function, jump discontinuity (f has different limits from the left and right side at a), piecewise continuous (if on every finite subinterval, it has only a finite number of discontinuities, all of which are jump discontinuities), e.g. ceiling function
930ABE6A-AFB2-4CAA-B0B4-13A14BC01052
def: the limit of a function f(x) as x approaches a is infinity if for every positive integer N, there is an r > 0 such that f(x) > N for all 0 < abs(x - a) < r.
def: characteristic function
section 5.2 discontinuous functions
def: (metric space) continuous
AE226CBD-C638-4DF3-AA15-EC8E9E3F108C
1. f is continuous on X
2. for every sequence (x_n) converges to a, then the sequence (f(x_n)) converges to f(a)
3. for every open set U in Y, the set f^-1(U) is open in X.
thm: f be a function between two metric spaces, TFAE:
thm: f from X to Y, both are metric spaces, then for C in X, C compact, then f(C) is a compact set in Y. (actually in section 5.4, but not about metric)
thm: since C is compact, there exists a finite sub cover Valpha1,…Valphak such that maps to Ualpha1,…Ualphak is a finite subcover of f(C) (not on book)
1. f + g continuous at a
2. alphaf continuous at a
3. fg is continuous at a, when range of f and g is contained in R
4. f/g is continuous at a when g(a) != 0
thm: f, g continuous from R^n to R^m, alpha is constant, then:

thm: spa f maps a domain S in R^n into a subset T of R^m, and g maps T into R^l. If f is continuous at a in S and g is continuous at f(a) in T, then the function g(f(x)) is continuous at a. thus if f and g are continuous, then so is g(f(x))
section 5.3 properties of continuous functions
AFEA5BB9-42C1-4B1B-8BCD-CB14ABB7EB7D

extreme value theorem: C be a compact subset of R^n, and let f be a continuous function from C into R. then there are points a and b in C attaining the minimum and maximum values of f on C, that is, f(a) <= f(x) <= f(b) for all x in C.

\f0\b\fs28 \cf2 extreme value theorem: \f1\b0 \cf2 C be a compact subset of R^n, and let f be a continuous function from C into R. then there are points \f0\b \cf2 a \f1\b0 \cf2 and \f0\b \cf2 b \f1\b0 \cf2 in C attaining the minimum and maximum values of f on C, that is, f( \f0\b \cf2 a \f1\b0 \cf2 ) <= f( \f0\b \cf2 x \f1\b0 \cf2 ) <= f( \f0\b \cf2 b \f1\b0 \cf2 ) for all \f0\b \cf2 x \f1\b0 \cf2 in C.}
section 5.4 compactness and extreme values
BB3B9B02-4798-4E92-ACA2-8934BEEA1BEE

for f to be continuous, we fix both epsilon positive and a in S before obtaining the value of r. So the choice of r might depend on a as well as on epsilon. Uniform continuity means that for each epsilon positive, the value r positive that we obtain can be chosen independently of the point a. This is a subtle difference.

def: uniformly continuity (f from S in R^n into R^m is uniformly continuous if for every epsilon > 0, there is a positive real number r > 0 such that ||f(x) - f(a)|| < epsilon whenever ||x - a|| < r, x, a are in S.

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1265\cocoasubrtf190 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 HelveticaNeue-Light;\f1\fnil\fcharset0 HelveticaNeue-Bold;\f2\fnil\fcharset0 HelveticaNeue; } {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;\red6\green53\blue51;} \pard\tx560\tx1120\tx1680\tx2240\tx2800\tx3360\tx3920\tx4480\tx5040\tx5600\tx6160\tx6720\pardirnatural
\f0\fs28 \cf2 def: \f1\b \cf2 uniformly continuity \f2\b0 \cf2 (f from S in R^n into R^m is uniformly continuous if for every epsilon > 0, there is a positive real number r > 0 such that ||f( \f1\b \cf2 x \f2\b0 \cf2 ) - f( \f1\b \cf2 a \f2\b0 \cf2 )|| < epsilon whenever || \f1\b \cf2 x \f2\b0 \cf2 - \f1\b \cf2 a \f2\b0 \cf2 || < r, \f1\b \cf2 x, a \f2\b0 \cf2 are in S.}
what we have on book is: thm: suppose that C in R^n is compact and f from C to R^m is continuous, then f is uniformly continuous on C.
thm: f from X to Y be a continuous map of the compact metric space (X, d_X) to the metric space (Y, d_Y), then f is uniformly continuous (not on book)
proposition: every Lipschitz function is uniformly continuous.
corollary: every linear transformation from R^n to R^m is uniformly continuous
corollary: let f be a differentiable real-valued function on [a, b] with a bounded derivative. Then f is uniformly continuous on [a, b]
section 5.5 uniform continuity
4B1FCDAF-6A4A-4BE4-B577-96D809E1A4D9

def: separation (X be a metric space, a separation of X is a pair U, V of disjoint non-empty, open subset of X whose union is X), connected, not connected (a subset A of R^n is not connected if there are disjoint open sets U and V such that A in U union V and A intersection U != empty != A intersection V)
thm: a space X is connected iff the only subsets X that are both open and closed are X and empty set. (not on book)
thm: the image of a connected space under a continuous map is connected (not on book)
thm: the real line R is connected and so are intervals and rays (not on book)
Intermediate Value Theorem: f from X to R be a continuous map where X is a connected metric space, if a and b in X, f(a) < r < f(b), for some r in R, there exists c in X such that f(c) = r.
88CFECF7-00B0-4F83-9E49-D0EA3AECFA72
proposition: every Lipschitz function is uniformly continuous (from section 5.5)
corollary: every linear transformation from R^n to R^m is uniformly continuous (from section 5.5)
corollary: f be a differentiable real-valued function on [a, b] with a bounded derivative, then f is uniformly continuous on [a, b] (from section 5.5)
section 5.6 the intermediate value theorem
def: increasing, strictly increasing, decreasing, strictly decreasing, monotone, monotone increasing, monotone decreasing
proposition: if f is an increasing function on (a, b) then one-side limits of f exist at each point c for c in (a, b), then lim_x -> c^- f(x) <= f(c) <= lim_x -> c^+ f(x)
corollary: the only type of discontinuity that a monotone function on an interval can have is a jump discontinuity.
thm: a monotone function on [a, b] has at most countably many discontinuities.
section 5.7 monotone functions

def: norm (V is a vector space over R, a norm on V is a function || ` || on V taking values in [0, infinity) with the following properties: 1. positive definite, ||x|| = 0 iff x = 0; 2. homogeneous, ||alpha x|| = |alpha| ||x|| for all x in V and alpha in R; 3. triangle inequality…), normed vector space (we call the pair (V, || ` ||) a normed vector space)

\f0\fs28 \cf2 def: \f1\b \cf2 norm \f2\b0 \cf2 (V is a vector space over R, a norm on V is a function || ` || on V taking values in [0, infinity) with the following properties: 1. positive definite, ||x|| = 0 iff x = \f1\b \cf2 0 \f2\b0 \cf2 ; 2. homogeneous, ||alpha x|| = |alpha| ||x|| for all x in V and alpha in R; 3. triangle inequality\'85), \f1\b \cf2 normed vector space \f2\b0 \cf2 (we call the pair (V, || ` ||) \f1\b \cf2 \f2\b0 \cf2 a normed vector space)}
def: uniform norm on C(K), where K is a compact subset of R^n, C(K) denotes the vector space of all continuous real-valued functions on K. ( ||f||_infinity = sup|f(x)|, x in K)
AA5FD1C8-E553-4AD0-86FA-7B22F92E23FC
||f||_p = ( integral from a to b ( |f(x)|^p dx ) )^(1/p)
def: L^p norm on C[a, b]
section 7.1 normed vector spaces
def: converges, Cauchy sequence ( change the Euclidean norm into your customed norm)
a complete normed vector space is a Banach space.
def: complete ( (V, || ` ||) is complete if every Cauchy sequence in V converges to some vector in V.
def: open ball, open, closed.
proposition: a sequence (x_n) in a normed vectors space V converges to a vector x iff for each open set U containing x, there is an integer N such that x_n in U for all n > N.
section 7.2 topology in normed spaces

proposition: if {v_1,…v_n} is a linearly independent set in a normed vector space (V, || ` ||), then there exists positive constants 0<c<C such that for all a = (a_1,…a_n) in R^n, we have c||a||_2 <= || sum of a_i v_i from i=1 to n || <= C||a||_2

thm: T from R^n to V is Lipschitz (with L constant C), then T inverse from V to R^n is Lipschitz (with constant 1/c)
53598EA6-ED8A-498B-A5B5-2F5BAA1CCB08
corollary: a subset of finite-dimensional normed vector space A belongs to V is open/closed/bounded/compact iff T inverse (A) is open/closed/bounded/compact
corollary: a subset of a finite-dimensional normed vector space is compact iff it’s closed and bounded.

thm: (V, || ` ||) and W is a finite-dimensional subset of V. then for any v in V, there exists at least one closest point w* in W to v, that is, there is w* in W such that ||v - w*|| = inf{||v - w|| : w in W}
section 7.3 finite-dimensional normed spaces
1. positive definiteness
2. symmetry
for all x, y, z in V, and scalars a b in R, <ax + by, z> = a<x, z> + b<y, z>
3. bilinearity
def: inner product (on a vector space V) is a function <x, y> on pairs (x, y) of vectors in V times V taking values in R satisfying the following properties:
def: inner product space is a space with inner product
Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality: for all vectors x, y in an inner product space V, |<x,y>| <= ||x|| ||y||. equality holds iff x and y are collinear
7BABE69F-3A1E-4BF6-B4F4-C6AF162D2313
corollary: for f, g in C[a, b], we have | integral from a to b (f(x)g(x)dx) |<= (integral from a to b (f(x)^2 dx))^(1/2) (integral from a to b (g(x)^2 dx)^(1/2)
7C11BCE0-5EC2-490C-ADFA-E9AE5CFE8CA7
corollary: an inner product space V satisfies the triangle inequality ||x+y|| <= ||x|| + ||y|| for all x, y in V. moreover, if equality holds, then x and y are collinear
section 7.4 inner product spaces

orthogonal ( two vectors x and y such that <x,y> = 0), orthonormal (a collection of vectors {e_n: n in S} in V is called orthonormal if ||e_n|| = 1 for all n in S and <e_n, e_m> = 0 for any different n and m in S.)

lemma: {e_n} an orthonormal set, alpha_n are real coefficients, if w = sum alpha_n times e_n, then for each j, <w, e_j> = alpha_j. for any vector v, v-sum(<v, e_i>e_i is orthogonal to each e_j, where i is from 1 to n.
corollary: {e_n} is a finite orthonormal set, x is in span{e_1,…e_n} then x can be written uniquely as sum(<x, e_i>e_i) where i is from 1 to n. further, all orthonormal sets are linearly independent.
corollary: in a finite-dimensional vector space, an orthonormal set is a basis if and only if it is maximal with respect to being an orthonormal set.
The Gram-Schmidt Process
in particular, ||x||^2 = sum (alpha square) index from 1 to n

lemma: {e_n} an orthonormal set in an inner product space V. if x = sum each vector times its coefficient alpha_i, and y = sum of each vector times another coefficient beta_i, then <x, y> = sum(alpha_i times beta_i).
corollary: an inner product space of dimension n has an orthonormal basis with n elements.

def: a projection on an inner product space V is a linear map P: from V to V such that P^2 = P. in addition we say that P is an orthogonal projection if kerP = {v in V : Pv = 0} is orthogonal to ranP = PV
8755AAA3-33FA-4F6E-A56A-EAEE7AEF6333
A3CB2E39-B2DB-4724-A5CF-C1A22E429AC8
2. for all x in V, ||x||^2 = ||Px||^2 + ||(I-P)x||^2
D9B5BA72-5C96-4572-AAC6-B3297FA1CCDD
3. P is uniquely determined by its range.
in addition, if V is an inner product space and P is an orthogonal projection then
1. ker P = ran (I - P)
proposition: if P is a projection on a normed vector space V, then

projection theorem: Let M be a finite-dimensional subspace of an inner product space V and P the orthogonal projection with ran P = M. for all y in V, and all x in M, ||y-x||^2 = ||y-Py||^2 + ||Py-x||^2. in particular Py is the closest vector in M to y. If {e_n} is an orthonormal basis for M, then Py = sum(<y, e_j>e_j)
section 7.5 finite orthonormal sets
a well-defined inner product on PC[-pi, pi] given by <f, g> = 1/2pi * integral(from -pi to pi) f(x)g(x)dx
def: PC[-pi, pi] = the space of piecewise continuous functions, i.e. there is a partition of [-pi, pi] such that f is continuous on each subinterval
proposition: the functions {1, square root 2 *cosnx, square root 2 *sinnx; n>=1} form an orthonormal set in PC[-pi, pi] with this inner product.
FA0DE3D6-C4E4-4AA5-BABE-A167EEECFFD8

f ~ A_0 + sum(A_n*cosnx + B_n*sinnx), where A_0 = 1/2pi * integral (from -pi to pi) f(t)dt, and for n >= 1, A_n = 1/pi * integral(from -pi to pi) f(t)cosntdt, B_n = 1/pi * integral(from -pi to pi) f(t)sinntdt.
D112ABC8-AD1D-4DEC-B5AE-3B55A1A68591
the sequences (A_n) where n >= 0, and (B_n) where n >= 1 are the Fourier coefficients
def: trigonometric polynomial (…), Fourier series (the Fourier series of a piecewise continuous function f: from [-pi, pi] to R is:
section 7.6 Fourier series
Bessel’s inequality: Let S be a subset of N and let {e_n : n in S} be an orthonormal set in an inner product space V. for x in V, sigma|<x, e_n>|^2 <= ||x||^2
def: A Hilbert space is a complete inner product space.
thm: the inner product space l^2 is complete.
def: in a Hilbert space, consider a set of vectors S, spanS^bar = closure of the linear subspace spanned by S, closed span.

Parseval’s Theorem: let S be a subset of N and E = {e_n : n in S} be an orthonormal set in a Hilbert space H. Then the subspace M = spanE^bar consists of all vectors x = sigma(alpha_n * e_n) where the coefficient sequence (alpha_n) belongs to l^2. Further, for x in H, then x in M iff the Bessel’s inequality is hold.
corollary: let E = {e_n : n in S} be an orthonormal set in a Hilbert space H. then there is a continuous linear orthogonal projection P_M of H onto M = spanE^bar given by P_M_x = sigma(<x, e_n>e_n)
corollary: if E = {e_i : i >= 1} is an orthonormal basis for a Hilbert space H, every vector x in H may be uniquely expressed as x = sigma(<x, e_i>e_i)
section 7.7 orthogonal expansions and Hilbert spaces
CHAPTER 7 Norms and Inner Products
def: let (f_n) be a sequence of functions from S belongs to R^n into R_m. This sequence converges pointwise to a function f if: lim_k to infinity f_k(x) = f(x) for all x in S.

def: let (f_k) be a sequence of functions from S belongs to R^n into R_m. This sequence converges uniformly to a function f if for every epsilon > 0, there is an integer N such that ||f_k(x) - f(x)|| < epsilon for all x in S and k >= N

thm: given S is a subset of R_n and a sequence of functions (f_k) in C(S, R^m), (f_k) converges uniformly to f iff f_k - f is in C_b(S, R^m) for all k sufficiently large and lim_k to infinity ||f_k - f||_infinity = 0
when we have ||f||_infinity = sup||f(x)||_2
section 8.1 limits of functions
33B3ECD9-CDEA-46BA-94BF-AA9F26D0FECD
thm: (f_k) be a sequence of continuous functions mapping a subset S of R^n into R^m that converges uniformly to a function f. Then f is continuous.
completeness theorem for C(K, R^m): if K is a subset of R^n, K is compact, the space C(K, R^m) of all continuous R^m-valued functions on K with the sup norm is complete.

thm: let (f_n) be a sequence of continuous functions on [a, b] converging uniformly to f(x), let c in [a, b], then F_n(x) = integral from c to x(f_n(t)dt), n>=1, converge uniformly on [a, b] to F(x) = integral from c to x (f(t)dt).

EC6C95B9-967A-48E2-8CD8-BBEACC1863D4

def: S is a subset of R^n, say that a series of functions (f_k) from S to R^m is uniformly Cauchy on S if for every epsilon > 0, there is an N such that ||sigma from i=k+1 to l (f_i(x))||_infinity <= epsilon whenever x is in S and l>k>=N.
thm: a series of functions converges uniformly if and only if it is uniformly Cauchy.

Weierstrass M-test: suppose that a_k(x) is a sequence of functions on S belongs to R^n into R^m, (M_k) is a sequence of real numbers and there is N such that for all k>= N and all x in S, ||a_k||_infinity = sup||a_k(x)|| <= M_k, if sigma(M_k) converges, then the series sigma(a_k(x)) converges uniformly on S.

1E95FBFD-28A3-4F9D-BCC0-72FD58CD7378
Arzelà-Ascoli Theorem: let K be a compact subset of R^n. A subset F of C(K, R^m) is compact iff it is closed, bounded and equicontinuous.

a family of functions F mapping a set S belongs to R^n into R^m is equicontinuous at a point a in S if for every epsilon > 0, there is an r > 0 such that ||f(x) - f(a)|| < epsilon whenever ||x - a|| < r and f is in F.
the family F is equicontinuous on a set S if it is equicontinuous at every point in S.
the family F is uniformly equicontinuous on S if for each epsilon > 0, there is an r > 0 such that ||f(x) - f(y)|| < epsilon whenever ||x-y|| < r, x, y in S and f in F.
def: equicontinuous
lemma: K be a compact subset of R^n, a compact subset F of C(K, R^m) is equicontinuous
BBABFEA5-EBC4-469C-8664-D3CE976C050E
proposition: F is an equicontinuous family of functions on a compact set, then it is uniformly equicontinuous.

def: metric (on a set X is a function defined on X times X taking values in [0, infinity) with the following properties:
note that the difference between here and those previous definitions is that we are going to use metric instead of euclidean norm
def: ball, open, converge, closed, closure
def: Cauchy, complete
thm: a subset of a complete metric space is complete iff it is closed.
section 9.1 definitions and examples
C91A28BA-9998-4BD9-BE49-70AEA28ABEDD
****NOTE: the old definition of compactness is actually sequential compactness.
open cover: a collection of open sets in X is called an open cover of Y if Y is in the union of these open sets
subcover: a subcover of Y is a subcollection for some B in A that is still a cover of Y.
in particular if B is finite, then it is a finite subcover
def: open cover, sub cover, finite subcover
finite intersection property: for a collection of closed sets, if every finite subcollection has nonempty intersection.

def: compact (a metric space X is compact if every open cover of X has a finite subcover), sequentially compact (a metric space X is sequentially compact if every sequence of points in X has a convergent subsequence), totally bounded (a metric space X is totally bounded if for every epsilon > 0, there are finitely many points x_1, …, x_k in X such that the ball centred at those points is an open cover.
1. X is compact
2. Every collection of closed subsets of X with the finite intersection property has nonempty intersection
3. X is sequentially compact
4. X is complete and totally bounded
Borel-Lebesgue Theorem: for a metric space X, TFAE:

Lebesgue number lemma: if the metric space is compact and an open cover of X is given, then there exists a number delta > 0 such that every subset of X having diameter less than delta is contained in some member of the cover. (not on book)
